net.java.dev.designgridlayout
Class DesignGridLayout

java.lang.Object
  net.java.dev.designgridlayout.DesignGridLayout
All Implemented Interfaces:
LayoutManager
public class DesignGridLayout
extends Object
implements LayoutManager

Swing LayoutManager that implements "Canonical Grids" as used by graphic artists to design magazines, posters, forms...

Canonical grids are useful for, but not limited to, all kinds of forms mostly used in UI dialogs.

DesignGridLayout provides a convenient API to have automatically well-balanced canonical grids panels. With this API, there is no need for any graphical designer.

Typically, DesignGridLayout will be used as follows: 

 public class MyPanel extends JPanel {
     public MyPanel() {
         DesignGridLayout layout = new DesignGridLayout(this);
         //...
         layout.row().grid(labelA).add(fieldA);
         layout.row().grid(labelB).add(fieldB);
         //...
         layout.row().center().add(okButton, cancelButton);
         }
         //...

Author:
Jason Aaron Osgood, Jean-Francois Poilpret

Constructor Detail

DesignGridLayout

public DesignGridLayout(Container parent)
Builds a DesignGridLayout instance attached to a Container. This instance should be then used to add rows and components to the parent container.

Note that this constructor auomatically calls parent.setLayout(this) so you don't need to call it yourself.

In no way should the Container.add(java.awt.Component) and Container.remove(int) ever be used with parent.

Parameters:
parent - the container for which we want to use DesignGridLayout; cannot be null.
Method Detail

margins

public DesignGridLayout margins(double top,
                                double left,
                                double bottom,
                                double right)
Define special margins ratios for the parent container. You normally won't use this method because DesignGridLayout uses the best margin values for the current used Look and Feel. However, it may be useful when you use DesignGridLayout in special containers such as views used in a docking-based application, in which case you would rather avoid wasting too much space as margins for each single docked view.

Parameters:
top - top margin ratio that will be applied to the standard top margin for the current platform
left - left margin ratio that will be applied to the standard left margin for the current platform
bottom - bottom margin ratio that will be applied to the standard bottom margin for the current platform
right - right margin ratio that will be applied to the standard right margin for the current platform
Returns:
this instance of DesignGridLayout, allowing for chained calls to other methods (also known as "fluent API")

margins

public DesignGridLayout margins(double ratio)
Define a special margins ratio for the parent container. You normally won't use this method because DesignGridLayout uses the best margin values for the current used Look and Feel. However, it may be useful when you use DesignGridLayout in special containers such as views used in a docking-based application, in which case you would rather avoid wasting too much space as margins for each single docked view.

Parameters:
ratio - the ratio to apply to each standard margin for the current platform
Returns:
this instance of DesignGridLayout, allowing for chained calls to other methods (also known as "fluent API")

row

public IRowCreator row()
Creates a new row. The type of the row is not determined yet, but will be determined by the chained call performed on the returned IRowCreator.

The new row is located under the previously created row, which means that each line of code using this method creates a new row and all lines can be read as defining the visual UI of the container.

Note that this method has no effect on the layout if there's no chained call on the returned IRowCreator (ie when you have code like layout.row();).

Returns:
a new IRowCreator that must be used to set the actual type of the created row.

row

public IRowCreator row(double verticalWeight)
Creates a new row. The type of the row is not determined yet, but will be determined by the chained call performed on the returned IRowCreator.

The new row is located under the previously created row, which means that each line of code using this method creates a new row and all lines can be read as defining the visual UI of the container.

This method explicitly sets the vertical growth weight for this row; this is applicable only if this row contains at least one component that can vary in height (eg JScrollPane, vertical JSlider); if this row has no such component, then calling this method will have no impact, ie this row will always have a fixed height.

Note that this method has no effect on the layout if there's no chained call on the returned IRowCreator (ie when you have code like layout.row();).

Important! Note that it is generally useless to use this method: DesignGridLayout will by default assign a weight of 1.0 to all rows that should have a variable height, hence during resize, extra height will be equally split to all such rows. Use this method only if you want a row to get more (verticalWeight > 1.0) or less (verticalWeight < 1.0) extra height than other rows.

Parameters:
verticalWeight - the weight given to this row when DesignGridLayout distributes extra height during resize actions; must be >= 0.0 or the value will be ignored.
Returns:
a new IRowCreator that must be used to set the actual type of the created row.
See Also:
row()

emptyRow

public void emptyRow()
Adds a new empty row to the container. This row will never contain any component and is used only for introducing vertical space between rows or groups of rows. The height of that row is automatically calculated based on the fact that the previously-added row and the next-added row contain unrelated components.
